verses.text: As Peter and John were speaking to the people, the priests, the commander of the temple, and the Sadducees came up to them,
verses.comment: The priests and Sadducees were Jewish leaders who held authority in the temple; Sadducees denied the resurrection (Matt 22:23).

verses.text: greatly annoyed because they were teaching the people and proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection from the dead.
verses.comment: Proclaiming resurrection in Jesus directly challenged Sadducees' doctrine and affirmed the core Gospel message (1 Cor 15:3–4).

verses.text: They laid hands on them and put them in custody until the next day, for it was already evening.
verses.comment: Arresting Peter and John shows the growing opposition and the risk the apostles faced in preaching Christ publicly.

verses.text: But many of those who heard the word believed, and the number of the men came to about five thousand.
verses.comment: The rapid increase in believers emphasizes the power and divine confirmation of the apostolic mission.

verses.text: On the next day, their rulers, elders, and scribes gathered together in Jerusalem,
verses.comment: These are the members of the Sanhedrin, the Jewish ruling council, who also condemned Jesus (Matt 26:59).

verses.text: with Annas the high priest, and Caiaphas and John and Alexander, and all who were of the high priestly family.
verses.comment: Annas and Caiaphas were also involved in Jesus' trial. The continuity highlights the challenge the apostles faced.

verses.text: When they had set them in the midst, they inquired, 'By what power or by what name did you do this?'
verses.comment: This question echoes the scrutiny Jesus faced; the 'name' implies authority—a key theme in apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, 'Rulers of the people and elders,
verses.comment: Peter speaks boldly by the Spirit, fulfilling Jesus' promise (Luke 12:12), demonstrating Spirit-guided leadership.

verses.text: If we are being examined today about a good deed done to a crippled man, by what means he was healed,
verses.comment: Peter points to the miracle as an act of mercy, not subversion, placing the focus on God’s work.

verses.text: let it be known to all of you and to all the people of Israel that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified, whom God raised from the dead, by him this man stands here before you healed.
verses.comment: Peter proclaims the resurrection and power in Jesus' name—core apostolic teaching.

verses.text: This Jesus is the stone that was rejected by you, the builders, which has become the cornerstone.
verses.comment: Peter quotes Psalm 118:22, emphasizing fulfilled prophecy and Jesus as the foundation of the one true Church.

verses.text: And there is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.
verses.comment: Affirms the uniqueness of Christ as Savior—an exclusive claim foundational to Christian faith.

verses.text: Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John and perceived that they were uneducated, ordinary men, they were amazed; and they recognized that they had been with Jesus.
verses.comment: The apostles’ authority and wisdom comes from being with Christ and being filled with the Spirit, not from human schooling.

verses.text: But seeing the man who was healed standing with them, they could say nothing in opposition.
verses.comment: The obvious miracle silenced their critics—a sign often accompanies true teaching (Mark 16:20).

verses.text: But when they had commanded them to leave the council, they conferred with one another,
verses.comment: The Sanhedrin needed privacy to decide how to address this undeniable sign.

verses.text: saying, 'What shall we do with these men? For that a notable sign has been performed through them is evident to all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.'
verses.comment: Even Jesus' opponents acknowledge the reality of the miracle—pointing to an objective truth claim.

verses.text: But so that this may not spread any further among the people, let us warn them to speak no more to anyone in this name.'
verses.comment: Religious authorities are concerned not with truth, but with maintaining power, contrasted with apostolic obedience to God.

verses.text: So they called them and ordered them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus.
verses.comment: The prohibition was specifically against the authoritative teaching in Jesus’ name—a challenge to apostolic succession.

verses.text: But Peter and John answered them, 'Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God, you must judge,
verses.comment: The Church’s leaders must obey God above men, affirming divine authority over earthly authority.

verses.text: for we cannot but speak about what we have seen and heard.'
verses.comment: The leaders are authentic witnesses, compelled by the Holy Spirit, echoing the Church's call to mission.

verses.text: And when they had further threatened them, they let them go, finding no way to punish them, because of the people; for all were praising God for what had happened.
verses.comment: Public recognition of God’s miracle prevented the authorities from acting further, indicating the effect of signs and wonders in the early Church.

verses.text: For the man on whom this sign of healing was performed was more than forty years old.
verses.comment: The detail of the man’s age stresses the gravity and public nature of the miracle—affirming apostolic authority.

verses.text: When they were released, they went to their own people and reported all that the chief priests and the elders had said to them.
verses.comment: The apostles’ fellowship and unity marked one visible, faithful community—an apostolic characteristic.

verses.text: When they heard it, they lifted their voices together to God and said, 'Sovereign Lord, who made the heavens and the earth and the sea and all that is in them,
verses.comment: Their prayer begins by acknowledging God's sovereignty as Creator, aligning with traditional forms of Jewish prayer.

verses.text: 'who spoke by the Holy Spirit through the mouth of our father David, your servant, and said, ‘Why did the nations rage and the peoples plot in vain?’
verses.comment: References Psalm 2, which early Christians saw as messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ’s rejection and victory.

verses.text: ‘The kings of the earth took their stand, and the rulers were gathered together against the Lord and against his Anointed.’
verses.comment: ‘His Anointed’ means Messiah (Christ); here fulfilled in Jesus whom all the rulers opposed, yet he triumphed.

verses.text: For truly in this city there were gathered together against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with the Gentiles and the peoples of Israel,
verses.comment: Notes the fulfillment of prophecy: all the major authorities—Jewish and Gentile—opposed Jesus, God's chosen one.

verses.text: to do whatever your hand and your plan had predestined to take place.
verses.comment: Affirms God's providence—even opposition worked to accomplish salvation, echoing themes of divine sovereignty.

verses.text: Now, Lord, look upon their threats and grant to your servants to speak your word with all boldness,
verses.comment: The community asks for courage, not deliverance, demonstrating the Church's mission focus and reliance on grace.

verses.text: while you stretch out your hand to heal, and signs and wonders are performed through the name of your holy servant Jesus.'
verses.comment: Miracles continue to accompany apostolic ministry and prayer in Christ’s name, a mark of the authentic Church.

verses.text: And when they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and spoke the word of God with boldness.
verses.comment: Pentecostal imagery—a visible sign of the Spirit indicates God’s endorsement of their unity and mission.

verses.text: Now the full number of those who believed were of one heart and soul, and no one said that any of the things that belonged to him was his own, but they had everything in common.
verses.comment: The radical unity and sharing prefigure the ideal of true Christian fellowship—oneness as the body of Christ.

verses.text: And with great power the apostles were giving their testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great grace was upon them all.
verses.comment: The apostles' authority and grace underscore the importance of apostolic tradition and continuity.

verses.text: There was not a needy person among them, for as many as were owners of lands or houses sold them and brought the proceeds of what was sold
verses.comment: Such generosity fulfills Old Testament commandments and echoes Deuteronomy 15:4.

verses.text: and laid it at the apostles' feet, and it was distributed to each as any had need.
verses.comment: Laying offerings at the apostles’ feet shows trust in their leadership and highlights apostolic authority in the early Church.

verses.text: Thus Joseph, who was also called by the apostles Barnabas (which means son of encouragement), a Levite, a native of Cyprus,
verses.comment: Barnabas will become a key leader; his identity as a Levite signals a continuity from Old to New Covenant priests.

verses.text: sold a field that belonged to him and brought the money and laid it at the apostles' feet.
verses.comment: Barnabas’ example of giving to the leaders directly affirms apostolic stewardship—a vital theme in early Church structure.
